In fact, I would guess that Mario Scelba will be remembered longest for the fact
that he rebuilt the democratic coalition after it had fallen apart in the wake of the 1953
election. And I think this will be true whether democracy survives or fails in Italy.
This may surprise those of you who are familiar with Scelba*a work as interior minis¬
ter, when he rebuilt the national police and carabinieri and used them vigorously in
crucial postwar years to put down Communist demonstrations that got out of hand. And
certainly, Scelba today is best known both at home and abroad for that police job — the
organising of the famous "celere," ox flying squads, to cope with Communist and Fascist
violence in the squares of Italy*
But as a Iongrange proposition I will stick with my guess. I think that when the
political historians tackle this particular period they will single out Mario Soelba for
the fact that he rebuilt a democratic coalition when few believed it could be done.
Perhaps just a bit of background will help to put that job in focusI
Italy*s four democratic parties — the majority Christian Democrats, the Social
Democrats, Liberals and Hepublicans —* had joined forces and drawn up a unified slate of
candidates for the election of June, 1953. Together they had enacted an electoral law
carrying Scelba *s name that would have given them about 65 per cent of the seats in the
Chamber of Deputies if they had polled more than 50 per cent of the total vote. Partly
because of widespread resentment over that law, the democratic coalition fell just short
of its 50 per cent. And this setback caused the coalition to break up in bitter recrimin¬
ation after the election. Be Gasperi, whose name had been synonomous with Italian
political stability in the postwar period, tried to form a government compered only of
Christian Democrats — and failed. So did another Christian Democrat, Attilio Piccioni.
Finally, a third Christian Democrat, Giuseppe Pe.lla* managed in mid-August to form
a government and resolve the long summer crisis. At first, Pella himself referred to his
government as a kind of caretaker cabinet, to get the budget passed and allow the political
dust to settle.
Then Pella began to depend on the right-wing Monarchist party, which had more votes
in the Chamber than the three minor democratic parties together. Thus, the real signifi¬
cance of Pella*s four-month government was that it marked a turn away from the democratic
center and an uneasy and unofficial alliance between the Christian Democrats and the
Monarchists.
One Christian Democrat who didn*t like this situation at all was Mario Soelba. In
December of 1953, he made a peech in which he advocated a return to the democratic
coalition. He said this was the only effective way to bring needed social and economic
reforms as well as to fight communism. This speech was one factor in Pella*s downfall in
January, 1954, and a factor that eventually led President Luigi Einaudi to give Scelba the
job of doing what he had advocated! reconstructing the democ 3tic coalition.
It was a difficult taks. Scelba had to pay — with key cabinet jobs — for the 38
votes which the three minor parties could give him in the Chamber of deputies. And even
with these 38 he could count on a majority in the Chamber of only a few votes. And the
higher price had paid for this support, the more dissatisfaction he created in his own
Christian Democratic party.
